Jany 1775 now in possession of his Sister Mrs Whittemore—and he told me that Mrs Nehemiah Parsons had a file of Letters from my mother to Mr John Thaxter.— This Evening at 7 O’Clock, I delivered at the town Hall the introductory Lecture for the Season, before the Quincy Lyceum. Charles went with me.— The Hall was full, but not crowded— Home at 9.

I began the day this morning with the record of yesterday which I finished before breakfast— I then resumed my Chinese Lecture, and from the multiplication of matters for discussion in treating it, found that it cannot be properly considered in the compass of one Lecture; and made still more clearly the discovery of my own incompetency to discourse upon the subject at-all— And yet having undertaken it I must go through— The very first principles of the Laws of Nations are involved in the controversy, and the accredited writers, especially Vattel, rather offuscate than clarify the investigation— The History of China, and especially of the twenty-second of Tsing dynasty now occupying the throne, gives occasion for earnest enquiry, which I have not yet found the means to satisfy. I have thumbed over Vattel and Ward, and found sundry questions for debate. The Abbé Raynal’s Philosophical and political history of the European Establishments in the two Indies has an article concerning the origin of the Portuguese Settlement at Macao and a summary of the history of China, absolutely romantic— There was a fashion at the time when the Abbé wrote, among the philosophical French writers of extolling the Governments of all other Nations over that of France.— He himself was ultra-republican in all his opinions, and declamatory in his manner of presenting them; and yet he puffs up the Chinese government as if it were a model of perfection. The most absolute despotism upon earth, rotten with the filthiest corruptions affecting to look down with scorn upon all other Nations, one would suppose from his narritive the very model of perfection— It is impossible it shoul be true— A general description of China, translated from the French of the Abbe Grosier 1788 from which I have been unable to collect nothing of any value— An abstract in Mavors collection of voyages from the writings of the Jesuité Le Comte and Du Halde; not more profitable; and lastly Sir George Staunton’s account of Lord Macartney’s Embassy to China in 1792, which I had not even time to skim— There was rain early in the morn—and a heavy gale, with torrent showers was gathering the whole day— My Son, with his wife and three elder children dined and spent the day with us—and Ruth Turner— Captain Drew of Duxbury came to enquire the state of his petition before the house, for remission of a fine levied upon him at New-Orleans— I could not tell; but must ascertain at the approaching meeting of Congress.— Captain Drew said he was going to New-Orleans, and Europe again; but not to sail till after the 9th. of next Month. I wrote Letters to Mr Nelson Moore at Waltham, and the Revd. Charles W. Upham at Salem—

A Gale, almost a Hurricane, with heavy Showers of rain continued through the night and part of this morning.— The wind then subsided and it cleared up towards Night. Charles had some difficulty in getting home with his family and Ruth Turner who had been here at work. I was busily occupied all day.— Charles and his family dined with us, it being the last day before their return to the City for the Winter— Last Saturday Captain Josiah Bass came and introduced Mrs Harriet Spear who has a Son, enlisted as a boy in the Navy under the act of Congress, and now on board the Columbus in Boston Harbour.— Both mother and Son, are extremely anxious to obtain his discharge and she came to solicit my influence to obtain it— I advised her to write a letter to the Secretary of the Navy soliciting his discharge, and to send her Letter to me, promising to forward it, with an additional recommendation of my own— I have accordingly received her Letter, and this day, wrote to the Secretary of the Navy, enclosing it— I wrote also to Mr Nelson Moore, at Waltham; offering to deliver a Lecture there Saturday Evening of next week— At the dusk of evening I walked over the hill; the only exercise I have taken for two days— I continue my investigations for my Chinese Lecture, and deeply regret that I have not another month to examine, and discuss the whole subject— I am now on a critical analysis of the three first principles of the Law of Nations, laid down, by Vattel, and shewing their inconsistency with each other.— I am looking also for Chinese history, and especially for the succession of Emperors of the Mantchoo Tartar or Tsing Dynasty being the 22d. I find in the great Work of Du Halde that Tsong-te ascended the throne by conquest in 1644—but died immediately— His Son Chun-Tchi reigned seventeen years till 1661. succeeded by his son Kang-hi who reigned 60 years till 1722—then his son Yong-tching 13 years till 1735. the reigning Emperor when Du Halde’s work was published.—Then came Kien-Long—another reign of 61. years till 1796. when he abdicated in favour of his Son Kia-king— Kien-Long died in 1799 and Kia-King reigned till 1820. when the present Emperor succeeded— The newspapers still teem with the New-York plot and counterplot; the basest part of which is the tampering of the U.S. District Attorney, with two men of infamous character to run down the whig party with false charges of fraud at the Elections of 1838 and 1839. and the Star-chamber inquisitions of the Recorder Morris.

My Son went this morning into Boston, with his family for the Winter— I was distracted with the settlement of monthly bills, and with arrangements for our departure next week for Washington. My wife and family propose to go on Monday. I have to deliver Lectures next week at Charlestown, at Salem, at Waltham, and perhaps at Boston— And I propose to stay till after Monday the 9th. of next Month being the day of the Elections— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, and took an assortment of Bills and specie for the expenses of my family’s journey to Washington— At the town Hall where the Selectmen gave me a minute of the particulars of my tax bill for the town and County.— The Selectmen, are Charles A. Brown, Charles A. Cummings and Daniel Baxter— Cummings said he could not find the particular statement of my personal property, which my Son had given in— I called also at C. Gill’s shop and paid his bill for book-binding— Met J. A. Green in the Street, and requested him from this time to send my Quincy Patriot weekly to Washington— Mr Carr came with a subscription book for the whig Association reading room— I gave him a small contribution to purchase books for the room, but declined joining the association as a member having never been a member of any private political Society— Elizabeth C. Adams dined and spent the Evening here. Her brother John Quincy came and escorted her home.— I received this morning a Letter from Charles Johnston member of Congress from Dutchess County New-York, inviting me to deliver a Lecture at Poughkeepsie— I have also received similar applications, from Schenectady in New-York, and from Springfield in this State— Also from the College at Brunswick, to deliver the ΦB.K— Oration there next Summer. I find it impossible even to answer all these Letters; and fear I shall be obliged even to leave my lecture upon China unfinished— I took up this day Sir George Staunton’s account of Lord Macartney’s Embassy, and found much matter of entertainment, and much to the purpose of my Lecture— The name of the present Emperor is Taou-Kwang and he succeed Kia-King in 1820. This is therefore the 20th. year of his reign—

Day.— The Summer is gone— This day completes three Months since we arrived here from Washington.— Three weeks of the time I was absent on my trip to Halifax, New-Brunswick and Maine— I rise from 4 to 1/2 past 5. write and read newspapers till 8. Breakfast—read and write till 2. dine. Read and write till dark— Often an hour or two in the Evening— Otherwise with my family, Charles and his wife.
